Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing the behavior of microscopic systems. However, it is not a theory that is easy to understand. This has led to a number of attempts to develop a more intuitive foundation for quantum theory. One such attempt is the reconstruction program, which aims to provide a purely categorical foundation for quantum mechanics. In this paper, we provide a categorical foundation for quantum mechanics that is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest because of their extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic one. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian, and we show that myxozoans are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. We also show that myxozoan genomes are among the smallest reported in animals and that they are depleted in genes related to development and cell–cell communication. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the main factors that contribute to the severity of a disease. In this study, we show that the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2 is able to interfere with the nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) and, consequently, to impair the antiviral response. Our results provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used by SARS-CoV-2 to overcome the action of IFN. This study also contributes to the understanding of the role of the Nup98-Rae1 complex in the nuclear import process. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century. Meeting this demand will require increasing global crop production by 70% by 2050. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase to 86% under 4 °C of global warming. These results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which species compete for resources is often inferred from their trophic similarity, but this approach can be misleading. We show that, even among closely related species, diet composition can differ substantially, and that this can have important consequences for coexistence. Our results suggest that the extent to which species compete for resources may be more tightly linked to the diversity of resources than to the diversity of species.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only 2 wk of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses expect to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris by nano-fragmentation and transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes. This study is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The age of the solar system is one of the most fundamental facts in science. It is also one of the most difficult to determine. We determined the age of the solar system by measuring the exposure age of presolar grains.

The world’s fishing fleet has doubled in size over the last 70 y, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. Despite this expansion, the effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries’ resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. It is also one of the most difficult to understand. Here, we show that the ability to reproduce is strongly limited by the mother’s metabolic power.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process, and patients die within a few years after disease onset. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This suggests that VX-765, a drug that is currently in clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the therapeutic potential of VX-765 in a mouse model of MSA. This study also provides a rationale for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors in the treatment of other neurodegenerative disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, regulates blood pressure, and controls inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cell clusters that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is highly efficient in the transmission of information, but the nature of the communication channels has not been well understood. Here, we show that the communication channels are not only short but also form a small-world network, which is a rare configuration in nature. This finding provides a fundamental understanding of the design of the endothelial network and its role in the control of cardiovascular function. This article is protected by copyright. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to understand the pandemic, inform policy, and guide public health interventions. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the information is often not available in a common format. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available. The data are available in a common format, and are updated daily. We believe that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers, policy makers, and epidemiological modelers.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This structural coupling is essential for the gating of these channels. We have identified a key residue for this allosteric communication. This residue is located in the activation gate and, interestingly, it is the only residue in this part of the channel that is conserved among the three studied channels. We have shown that this residue is crucial for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The composition of the gut microbiome is influenced by the host, the diet, and the gut microbiota itself. The gut microbiome is also a source of natural products that can be used to treat disease. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products. These natural products could be used to treat disease.

Anxiety is a common feature of many psychiatric disorders, and the brain energy metabolism is known to be altered in anxiety. Here we show that anxiety influences social behavior and that this effect is mediated by the brain energy metabolism.

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the current design paradigm is limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture composite structures with multiple materials that can be digitally synthesized to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture complex structures with multiple materials and can be applied to a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major component of the oxygen transport system in the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key element in the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is downregulated in the adult bone marrow. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is required for the fetal-to-adult switch in hemoglobin expression. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of the hemoglobin system in humans. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a major cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to current therapies. Thus, there is a need to develop new strategies to combat cancer. Here, we show that targeting the mTORC1 pathway in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT pathway mutation sensitizes them to ferroptosis induction, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This strategy resulted in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. Thus, ferroptosis may be a promising approach for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. It is a major risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of heart failure management. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI proteins, which are up-regulated in hypertensive VSMCs. Our findings may help to explain the association of LCCBs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies to reduce the risk of heart failure development in patients treated with LCCBs. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, since the evolution of pathogens is fast and efficient. We present a rational design strategy to overcome this problem. We used computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome to screen a library of acylide antibiotics. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and we show that it is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, the current standard of care. This compound is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. This strategy can be applied to other antibiotic classes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and can be used in a wide range of problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. From

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep, with the use of electronic devices phase-delaying the circadian clock, suppressing melatonin, and reducing the quality of the next night’s sleep. These effects are likely to have important consequences for performance, health, and safety.

One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the Younger Dryas cooling at ∼12.9 ka. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of the bulk samples and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites are consistent with a terrestrial origin, and that the YDB spherules are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our results show that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes. These results have important implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity and the origin of plant-feeding beetles. They also suggest that the evolution of plant-feeding beetles may be a key to understanding the origin of animal diversity.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibody drugs. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of culture, the transmission of knowledge, and the design of education and training systems. They also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to the innovation and adaptation of artifacts.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE4 allele. APOE is a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. Here, we show that APOE is critical for the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is a normal process of synapse elimination that occurs in the healthy brain. We also show that APOE is critical for the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to AD pathogenesis. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with AD risk in part because of defective synapse pruning by astrocytes. This hypothesis is testable in animal models. It may also be relevant to the pathogenesis of other neurodegenerative diseases.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is about 1,700 km in diameter and 1,500 km in height. It is the only solid ball in the universe. It is also the only solid ball that is rotating faster than it is falling apart. The inner core is the most mysterious part of the Earth. It is also the most important part of the Earth. It is the source of the Earth's magnetic field, which protects life on the surface from the sun's radiation. It is the source of the Earth's heat, which is the main source of the Earth's interior. It is the source of the Earth's rotation, which is the main source of the Earth's day.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are consistent with the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors that characterize marijuana abuse. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

Language is a uniquely powerful form of communication, and the human brain is uniquely capable of language comprehension. Here, we show that the most powerful deep learning models of language processing are also the most powerful models of the human brain responses to language. These results provide computational evidence for the fundamental role of predictive processing in the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is not clear how to apply DL to problems that are difficult or impossible to solve using current methods. We show that there are problems in science and engineering where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. Our results imply a classification theory describing conditions under which one can compute stable NNs in inverse problems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “crisis of cognition.” This paper shows that this is not only a metaphor but a serious problem. The classic experiment on the psychology of exponential growth is discussed as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining a study in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and its etiology has been the subject of much speculation. Here we report the genome sequence of a human leprosy bacillus, M. lepromatosis, and show that it is closely related to the leprosy bacillus, M. leprae, but is also capable of causing a distinct disease. This finding has important implications for understanding the evolution of the leprosy disease complex and the origin of the disease. (Read more)

Entanglement and entropy are central concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also key ingredients in the description of the thermodynamic limit of isolated systems. However, the dynamics of these quantities is not trivial in general, and it is not even known whether the entropy of a system in thermal equilibrium is the entropy of the corresponding statistical ensemble. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit is governed by a few simple rules, which are based on the quasiparticle picture of entanglement. These rules are exact in the case of integrable systems, and they lead to a complete understanding of the dynamics of entanglement in general systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a global response. The only currently available vaccine, developed by the University of Oxford and the pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca, is not suitable for mass vaccination due to its high cost and limited availability. Here, we describe a live attenuated vaccine candidate that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature, thus overcoming the current limitations of the Oxford–AstraZeneca vaccine. This vaccine candidate is highly protective in a relevant hamster model and has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its history is important for understanding the evolution of human populations and the development of modern medicine. We developed a mathematical model for the spread of plague by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a better understanding of the history of plague and its vectors, which is important for the development of effective control measures against the current pandemic.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important aspects of animal biology. It is the organ that has allowed animals to become the most successful group of organisms on Earth. However, the evolution of brain size is not the only way to measure the evolution of brain power. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only way to measure the evolution of brain power.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria has been the subject of intense study, but its function in the cell as a whole has been less well characterized. We have shown that TRAP1 is required for the maintenance of mitochondrial function and for the regulation of the metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis. These findings have implications for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and other diseases.

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, which is essential for the structure and function of all cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled, and they can also be cross-linked by proteins. The latter process is important for the stability of the cytoskeleton. Here, we show that the proteins cofilin and ADF/cofilin can sever cross-linked actin filaments, and that the severing rate is enhanced by a mechanical torque. This mechanism is critical for the function of the cytoskeleton in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in conjunction with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island was settled by different groups from Africa and Asia, with a recent demographic growth. In addition, we found that the settlement of Madagascar was not homogeneous, and that the genetic diversity is influenced by geography. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar, and they can be used to improve the interpretation of the genomic data from other islands.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but is controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that people’s own emotions are influenced by the emotions of others. This work suggests that in-person interaction is not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, and for the study of the influence of others on human behavior.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a relatively recent discovery, and their impact on mRNA function is just beginning to be understood. Here we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications in coding regions of mRNAs, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest impact on translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from that codon. These findings have implications for the function of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs and the translation of mRNAs in general. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is one of the most striking features of mammalian evolution. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal clades. This result is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. It replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the physical and chemical conditions in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense and respond to the physical properties of surfaces. This mechanosensing mechanism is essential for the persistence of the bacterium in the environment and its ability to cause disease.

The use of pesticides in agriculture is a major driver of global biodiversity loss. However, the extent of the problem is not fully understood because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of the occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and their impact on the biological integrity of aquatic ecosystems. Our results show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to global biodiversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the virus responsible for the disease has spread to many animal species. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is widespread in North America. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of the virus. This study is a significant step forward in understanding the role of wildlife in the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the search for its cause has been ongoing for more than a century. The current understanding of the disease is that it is caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors, and that it is characterized by the presence of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. However, the cause of the disease is still unknown, and the search for the cause continues. Here, we show that the amyloid precursor protein (APP) transgenic rat model of AD is characterized by a neuron-specific inflammatory response, which may be a significant contributor to the disease. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present evidence from the site of Maresha, Israel, that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was practiced in the Hellenistic period.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have applied this method to the maltose binding protein, which is known to have a complex folding pathway. We find that the folding of the protein is composed of two steps.

The accumulation of RNA molecules capped with dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress conditions has been shown to be a mechanism for bacterial adaptation. However, the mechanism by which this capping occurs and the enzymes involved in its removal remain unknown. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove Np4 capping from the 5′ end of RNA molecules, also removes capping from the 5′ end of other RNAs, including those that are triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated. This finding has important implications for the mechanism of decapping and the role of this process in bacterial stress adaptation. (Read more)

Sepsis is a major cause of mortality and morbidity worldwide. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and proliferation in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of the biomass of different taxa is still lacking. Here, we assemble the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also show that the biomass of plants is about two orders of magnitude higher than that of animals, and that animals are mainly marine. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

We present a model of self-organized criticality (SOC) in the context of tropical mathematics. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, it is not a perfect material, and it has some limitations. One of the most important limitations is that it is not a perfect conductor. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and we show the conditions for metallization. This work can help to improve the properties of diamond and make it a more attractive material for many applications.

The ability of plants to defend themselves against fungal pathogens is well known. However, the ability of plants to defend themselves against bacterial pathogens is not as well known. This work shows that a small peptide can be used to defend plants against fungal pathogens. This work also shows that the peptide can be used to defend plants against fungal pathogens in the field. This work is important because it shows that a small peptide can be used to defend plants against fungal pathogens, and it is important because it shows that the peptide can be used in the field.

The male–female reproductive interface is the site of the most intimate interactions between the sexes. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these contributions are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, and has only recently begun to be explored. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and provides a resource for future studies of the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar, to simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth is a key factor in the origin of life, as it is the temperature at which the chemical reactions that led to the origin of life could have occurred. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the early Earth, based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and cell function. They are classified into different families, each with its own unique structure and function. The K+ channel family is the largest and most diverse, with more than 500 members. The K+ channel family is also the most important in cell function, as it regulates the flow of ions that are essential for life. This article focuses on the K+ channel family’s largest subfamily, the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel, which is the most abundant K+ channel in the heart. We found that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This article provides a new perspective on the function of the BK channel and its subfamily. It also provides a new perspective on the function of the K+ channel family as a whole. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the host cell, and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the red blood cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding has major implications for our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This may have important implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Read more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, it is not a perfect material, and it has some limitations. One of the most important limitations is that it is not a perfect conductor. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and we demonstrate the pathway to metallization in six-dimensional strain space. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have important implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza transmission and severity of disease. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the impact of dry air on disease outcome, which may be useful for the development of therapeutic strategies to combat influenza

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic phrases from the bottom up. However, whether and how this process unfolds in the brain is unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be essential for language comprehension and may be disrupted in language disorders.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer, and thus a major area of research. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level but differ in their regulation. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, and that this differential regulation is important for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway. This may be a general feature of redundant genes, and may be important for the development of the organism.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the search for the neural circuits that control food intake is a major focus of neuroscience. Here we describe a circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key enabling technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley.

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.
Animals are able to hear the world around them, but how they do this is very different from each other. This article shows that the spider can hear the world without a body.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies worldwide. Vaccine development has been a critical response, and several promising candidates have been approved. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. Here we report the design and characterization of a variant of the RBD protein, which is a key component of the viral spike protein, that is suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered protein may be a cost-effective and scalable vaccine candidate for global access. We show that the zebrafish ALK homologue, DrLtk, is activated by the three zebrafish ALKALs. We further show that the loss of DrLtk and the three DrALKs causes distinct patterns of iridophore loss in the zebrafish. These results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/LTK family receptors in neural crest development. This is the first time that a ligand–receptor complex has been shown to be involved in the development of a specific tissue in a vertebrate. This finding may have implications for the understanding of the evolution of ligand–receptor complexes and their involvement in development. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its origin is a mystery that has been debated for centuries. Here, we present the largest collection of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes to date, which provide insights into the evolution of this pathogen and its early dispersal across Eurasia. We show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic was already present in the Eurasian Late Neolithic, and that the disease spread rapidly across continents throughout this period. These data provide a more complete picture of the early history of plague, which will be important for understanding the origins of this disease and its impact on human history. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural systems on grassland-derived Mollisols has led to massive C losses to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated organic carbon, but only when applied in a holistic, multidimensional way. These results highlight the importance of integrating crop rotations, cover crops, and manure applications with perennial grasslands and rotational grazing to mitigate climate change. This approach can be applied to other agricultural systems on Mollisols worldwide. Our findings have important implications for the design of climate-smart agricultural policies and the development of sustainable agricultural systems. This article is protected by copyright. The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. Validating the risk assessment, the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. The publicly accessible SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the mechanisms that underlie this trait are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this pigment in other plants. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the ecology and evolution of plants and animals.

We present a study of the genetic structure of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived in the 5th/6th century AD. Our results indicate that they had a very high genetic diversity, which is not surprising given the time period. However, the most striking result is that the collective genetic ancestry of the women suggests that they had a very different appearance than modern women. This is supported by the analysis of the functional variants in the genome, which indicates that they had a different phenotype than modern women.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origins of MERS-CoV and the risk of future cross-species transmissions of bat coronaviruses to humans. They also provide

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of a resource-scarce setting. We demonstrate the ability to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, which may be responsible for undifferentiated fevers in the region. We also show the utility of mNGS in the early detection of a chikungunya virus outbreak in Cambodia. This study highlights the potential of mNGS in resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and inform public health response. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human genome is replicated in the nucleus of the cell. This process is essential for the survival of the cell and the maintenance of the genetic information of the species. The process is complex and requires the cooperation of many proteins. One of the most important proteins is the sliding clamp, which is composed of proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) and the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of a neighborhood may be a useful indicator of its economic health.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab is evaluated. The results show that tocilizumab is an effective treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients, which can reduce mortality and improve the clinical condition immediately.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The existence of fungal natural products that bind copper and impact cellular copper content is surprising, as no such compounds have been found in fungi. We report the existence of xanthocillin-derived isocyanide fungal natural products that bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. The existence of such compounds in fungi suggests a role for these compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the interaction of fungi with other microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the interaction of fungi with other microbes. (Read more)

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph, in a drill sample of laminated mudstone at the base of the Gale crater sequence on Mars is significant because it is a key mineral for high-temperature sedimentary environments. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary sequence at the base of the Gale crater sequence indicates that the environment was a high-temperature, low-pressure one, which is consistent with the “Lake Gale” model. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary sequence at the base of the Gale crater sequence also indicates that the “Lake Gale” model is a viable model for the origin of the sedimentary rocks in Gale crater.
Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in response to the warming climate.

Th17 cells are a subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether Th17 cells are required for the development of disease or are merely mediators of the disease process. Here we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis and that they are able to support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of disease pathogenesis. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to the development of disease may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by the toxic effects of these mutations. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This will accelerate the development of therapeutics for ALS. This work is important for understanding the disease process and developing effective therapies for ALS. It will also be of interest to the broader scientific community.

The gut microbiota of arthropods is essential for their health and survival. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We identify a mechanism by which Anaplasma modifies the microbiota to facilitate colonization. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of vectors and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is poorly understood because of the limited known diversity of early branching members of the clade Pygostylia. Here, we describe a basal member of the clade Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia.
We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system, and that it is important to include the stratosphere in climate models.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of color polymorphism in vertebrates. They also provide a mechanism for the evolution of green color in anurans, which is a phenomenon called chlorosis. This study contributes to the understanding of the evolution of color in vertebrates. It also provides a mechanism for the evolution of green color in anurans.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and recurrence of the disease. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which increases the percentage of BCSCs. This study provides a mechanism for the role of hypoxia in the maintenance of BCSCs. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, and instead found that the use of several species of animal is consistent with the local availability of hides.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key parameter for understanding the causes of the event and its impact on the evolution of life on Earth.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the overactivation of the immune system. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and multifactorial, and the current treatment is limited. Here, we demonstrate that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in complex with the receptor, ACE2, at 8.3 Å resolution. We find that the D614G mutation has little effect on the structure of the spike protein, but that the mutant spike is able to bind ACE2 with higher affinity. This may facilitate the initial steps of viral entry. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may have a limited impact on the structure and function of the spike protein, but may have a significant impact on the infectivity of the virus.

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even when the action sets are discrete. The result is also new when the payoff functions are only measurable. The result is new even when the action sets are discrete.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We project that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, the largest decline since 2003, and a decline in life expectancy at age 65 y of 0.87 y, both of which are several times the decline for the total population. These projections imply that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase by nearly 40%, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby reversing progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Our projections highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected.

The chemical properties of an atom are the key to understanding the chemical behavior of a compound. The chemical hardness and the electronegativity are two of the most important properties of an atom. They are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively. We show that these properties decrease with pressure, and we discover that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a major step forward in the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between fire, climate, and the carbon cycle. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity. This has the potential to reduce warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in modulating the effects of climate change on the carbon cycle.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activity of a symbiotic bacterium, which in turn is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbes, which may be important for the maintenance of many animal-microbe associations. Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. We believe that this approach will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, and on the role of climate in the spread of infectious diseases. It also highlights the importance of climate in the spread of pathogens in the past, and in the development

Sea stars are important predators of algae and thus play a key role in the marine ecosystem. However, they are also a major food source for a variety of predators, including sea otters, sea lions, and humans. In the past few years, a disease has been observed in sea stars, leading to the mass mortality of at least 20 species. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the virus. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common forms of leukemia, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent settlement of the island, but with a sex bias and heterogeneities in the settlement of Madagascar. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It is also a step forward to understand the history of the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria are able to regulate the expression of genes in response to environmental changes. One of the most common mechanisms used by bacteria to regulate gene expression is the use of small RNAs. These RNAs are able to regulate the expression of other genes, and in some cases, they are able to encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that regulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibody drugs. (Show more)

Crop experts are the backbone of the agricultural sector, providing information on crop status that is critical for decision-making. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and difficult to aggregate and analyze. We show that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is the primary source of information on crop status, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited for quantitative analysis. We show that the CPC is robust to changes in the number of surveyors, and that it has long-term stability. We also discuss the origin of existing spatial and temporal biases in the CPC data, and demonstrate how the CPC can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our findings have important implications for the agricultural sector, and for the broader field of human-sensing.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the time constant of adaptation. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the time constant of adaptation.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains poorly understood. We present the results of a global synthesis of the literature on the temperature response of soil respiration. Our analysis provides evidence of a decrease in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration with increasing ambient temperature, which may have important implications for the global carbon cycle.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the origin and evolution of life on Earth. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is not well understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This process is likely to have played a key role in the origin of life. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in more than a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this event by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). This result highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the risk of drought in South Africa is increasing, and that the current drought is likely to be the first of many more to come. This will have severe consequences for the country’s water security. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they form are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy. The core of this process is the capture of solar radiation by chlorophyll, the primary photosynthetic pigment. The formation of the fifth ring of chlorophyll, the isocyclic ring, is the most important reaction in photosynthesis, and has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. Here we show that the formation of the isocyclic ring is catalyzed by three different enzymes.

Neuroinflammation is a major contributor to the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1). However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in astrocytes plays a key role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may provide a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of MS.
California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for mapping out the causal paths of autism. It also provides a potential target for the development of a behavioral-based diagnostic test for autism.
