This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. It finds that this is indeed the case, and that this negativity bias is present in 17 countries, across 6 continents, and in samples that are representative of the general population. The implications of these findings for the news media, and for the study of human cognition and behavior more broadly, are discussed.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the protein that forms the channel pore (Orai1) or the protein that senses CRAC channel activity (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify mutations in STIM1 and Orai1 that result in a spectrum of hematological and muscular abnormalities, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome. Our findings also expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and its role in human disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell autonomous and that the internalization of aggregates is required for the spread of pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of the membranes of the aggregates and the cell membrane. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are the most diverse group of mammals and are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated its immunosuppressant activity. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this protein. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus a metabolic target. Here we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target of pyrazolopyran inhibitors, and that these inhibitors are effective in cancer cell lines. We also show that formate, a one-carbon donor, is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These findings have implications for the design of metabolic inhibitors, and for the treatment of DLBCL. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. This suggests that the presence of these proteins in inclusions is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. This finding provides a mechanism for the formation of inclusions in ALS, and may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device configuration enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to have a broad impact on the fields of atom optics, quantum optics, and many-body physics.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification is still controversial. The study of Montsechia, an early flowering plant from the Cretaceous, provides new insights into the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the scientific community, as well as to the general public. Here we present the genomes of ancient viruses from human remains, which are of great interest to the scientific community. We show that the evolution of viruses is not as fast as previously thought, and that viruses have been associated with humans for a long time. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics.

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily over the last century, but the rate of rise has accelerated in recent decades. This acceleration is due to a combination of natural climate variability and human-induced changes in atmospheric and oceanic circulation. We show that the acceleration is well described by a quadratic in time, and that the rate of sea level rise is increasing. This result is consistent with the rate of climate change, and it implies that global mean sea level could rise 65 cm by 2100 compared with 2005.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the reasons for the rise in pain are not well understood. We show that pain is increasing in the United States, but that the rate of increase is greatest for those born after 1950, who are the least educated and have the lowest occupational status.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed transition state is a key determinant of enzyme specificity and catalytic efficiency. However, the structure of the enzyme-catalyzed intermediate is also critical, as it is the species that is ultimately observed in the crystal. Here, we show how the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes, can be determined by NMR-assisted crystallography. This structure is used to understand the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state, providing insight into the origin of the catalytic efficiency. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide insight into the reaction mechanism of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus infection with a high case fatality rate. There is a pressing need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that the broad-spectrum antiviral remdesivir, which is currently in clinical trials for the treatment of SARS, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This supports the use of remdesivir in the context of a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activity of a symbiotic bacterium, which in turn is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbes, which may be important for the maintenance of many animal-microbe associations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in schools by changing the mindset of teachers. This is a major finding, because suspension rates are a major predictor of adult incarceration and unemployment. The study also shows that it is possible to change the mindset of teachers, and that this can be done in a scalable way.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of the genome. However, the molecular mechanisms of how alkylation-induced lesions affect the function of the genome remain largely unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation-induced lesions on the function of the genome. We found that the presence of alkylation-induced lesions can affect the function of the genome in a regiospecific manner. This work provides important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of how DNA alkylation affects the function of the genome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins is required for efficient infection of human lung-derived cells, but not of other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Therefore, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may help to explain the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and may provide targets for therapeutic intervention. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. This study shows that it is possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a large catering environment, and that this increase in vegetarian meals is associated with a significant increase in sales of vegetarian meals. These results have important implications for the food system and for population health. They also provide evidence to support the use of simple interventions to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in catering environments. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in other environments, such as schools and hospitals.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome of a cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and find that the surfaceome is remodeled in a coordinated fashion, and that the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with a recently developed technique that allows for the analysis of the glycoproteome, and find that the glycoproteome is also remodeled in a coordinated fashion. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the cell surface as a potential target for cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that it is unlikely to have significant effects on electoral outcomes. This conclusion is important for policymakers, election administrators, and scholars interested in the effects of elections.

The COVID-19 pandemic is the most serious global health crisis in over a century. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is rapidly evolving and has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, and its mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in the rat brain, and that this effect is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), which contribute to the development of edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The scientific enterprise is in the midst of a revolution. The amount of data being generated is growing exponentially. The sophistication of the statistical methods being used to analyze these data is also growing exponentially. This paper addresses a fundamental challenge in this new era: How do we properly assess the strength of associations in the face of this explosion of data and statistical sophistication? We describe a set of methods that address this challenge. These methods are based on the principle that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the direct conversion of primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. Our study provides a useful tool for the generation of vascular ECs and the development of vascular regeneration. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
We report the discovery of a third group of RTKs, the augmentor receptors, which are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophore system.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular basis of T2D is well established, the mechanisms that regulate the progression of the disease remain to be elucidated. Here, we show that the STING protein is required for the maintenance of β-cell function and insulin secretion. These findings have important implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. Here, we identified a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. We also identified a sequence-dependent interaction between the viral RNA segments, which favors copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that it might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and might contribute to the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. These findings may lead to the development of athero-protective therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that people have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of a neighborhood may be a useful indicator of its economic health.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the time to detectable plasma viral load is very long, and that the rate of viral production is rapid. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by ∼2 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can help guide the design of effective antiviral strategies to combat the current ZIKV epidemic. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of anthropogenic stressors, including global warming. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This process is a key factor in the early stages of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help explain the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the host’s response to infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium and a dysbiotic microbiome. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between the tumors and the microbiome, which is critical for the maintenance of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond well to treatment. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 was up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, which enhanced the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). We also found that the expression of ROR1 enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice, and that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this study shows that the start of deglaciation was preceded by a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes similar to those associated with modern ozone depletion over Antarctica.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked in conservation and sustainability assessments. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries are a major source of animal protein for the world’s poor, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition are scarce. Our data can be used to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity, to prioritize conservation efforts, and to improve the sustainability of fisheries. This analysis highlights the importance of rivers and lakes for food security and biodiversity conservation.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve a high capacity and a low operating potential without triggering decomposition of water. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate is a fundamental property of the nervous system, which is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery is important because it provides a platform for the discovery of novel factors that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. It is also the target of many human diseases. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination activity in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that the activity of the genome is highly variable, with some regions of the genome recombining at a high rate, while others do not recombine at all. This distribution of recombination activity is similar to that found in yeast and mice, suggesting that it may be a conserved feature of eukaryotic genomes.

The brain is a dynamic system, and the study of its functional organization is a major challenge in neuroscience. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the brain can be used to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks. These networks are not only functionally relevant, but also show a clear progression in disease. This approach can be used to study the functional organization of the brain in health and disease.

We report the discovery of a 5′ cap structure in nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs that is composed of nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and is present on subsets of these transcripts. This finding extends the range of cap structures to include a third type of cap, which is found on a subset of mRNAs. The presence of this cap structure on specific subsets of mRNAs suggests that it may play a role in regulating mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The molecular mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the follow-up of people with diabetes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
This study provides a mechanism for the role of FSIP1 in drug sensitivity in TNBC. This may aid in the design of therapies for TNBC.

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the changes in the gut barrier. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit development is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. (Read more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because the loss of biodiversity is often considered in isolation from the impacts of global warming. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is important because the two factors are likely to interact in the future, as the world warms and biodiversity declines.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large number of neurons that fire in a place-dependent manner, and the precise organization of these neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record from a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that the organization of place cells is different from that of other neurons in MEC. This work provides a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and may help to elucidate the mechanisms of navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for the flowering of the host, but is required for the flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine system of the brain. It is caused by the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra and is associated with a loss of function of the dopamine system. Here, we show that the dopamine system is composed of subsystems that are affected in the disease. We also show that the dopamine system is composed of subsystems that are affected in the disease.

We are constantly interacting with others, and we often judge the quality of our interactions by how connected we feel. But how do we know when we are feeling connected? We show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by others to judge the quality of our interactions, and it is used by us to judge the quality of our interactions with others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of heart failure. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function.

Silicon (Si) is a ubiquitous element in the earth’s crust, and its beneficial effects on plant growth and development have been well documented. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a sustainable strategy to improve plant resistance against insect herbivores. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory in the brain. We show that the dynamics of the neuronal membrane potential can be decoupled from the dynamics of the firing rate. This allows for the maintenance of information in the form of adaptive conductances that reduce the firing rate. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and fiber for the world. However, they are difficult to genetically modify, which limits the development of new crops. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver functional biomolecules to plants, which can be used to silence a gene of interest. This work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the scientific community working on plant biology, synthetic biology, and nanotechnology.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the world’s lakes, but the majority of loading comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibit high nutrient loads for their size and bias toward dissolved inorganic forms. These findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong external forcing. We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the external forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of particles in a confining potential.
This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the effects of a class of antibodies on the brain. These findings may help in the development of new therapies for autoimmune encephalitis.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. However, the history of abrupt warming events is poorly understood, especially in the context of the Earth system’s response to such events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global seafloor anoxia, which was in turn driven by a global warming event. This study provides insights into the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming events and can help us to better understand the current warming. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world’s largest palm oil producers have committed to purchasing only “sustainable” palm oil, which is certified by the RSPO. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been quantified. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that the vast majority of certified areas are not yet free of forest loss. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having the desired impact on reducing deforestation in the tropics.

The exocyst complex is essential for the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the function of all eukaryotic cells. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sex determination is one of the most fundamental aspects of animal biology. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. Here we show that the interaction of multiple sex determination genes can result in a modular system of sexual polymorphism.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct forms of reactive oxygen species. One form is generated by the oxidation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts, which are formed by the photodegradation of the retinal pigment epithelium’s major storage product, the bisretinoid A2E. The other form is generated by the photooxidation of iron, which is a key component of the electron transport chain. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, as reflected in the transferrin receptor, impact the levels of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, which is the leading cause of blindness in the Western world. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key factor in the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it leads to the loss of morphological and functional diversity. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is linked to the evolution of tentilla, and that this morphological innovation has allowed for the evolution of specialization on different prey types. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of predatory niches, and the role of morphological innovation in the diversification of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus a metabolic target. Here we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target of the drug pyrazolopyran, and that this drug is effective in cancer. We also show that formate, a one-carbon donor, is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that this effect is enhanced in cancer. Finally, we show that DLBCL is uniquely dependent upon SHMT activity for glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic deficiency of DLBCL, which may be targetable with the drug pyrazolopyran. This work provides a framework for the design of metabolic inhibitors of cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change and is associated with a range of negative impacts on people’s health and livelihoods. However, little is known about the impact of deforestation on people’s diets, which are critical for health and well-being. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, which in turn can affect their vitamin A status. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Modern farm machinery is responsible for the vast majority of soil compaction, which is a major threat to soil productivity. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a significant increase in subsoil compaction, which now exceeds safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We also show that the total weight of modern farm vehicles is now comparable to that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that the effects of modern farm machinery on soil compaction may have been similar to those of sauropods in the past, and that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
